column1: William Harvey "Bill" Dana is a retired NASA test pilot and astronaut.
Dana was born in Pasadena, California on November 3, 1930.
He joined NASA after receiving a Master of Science degree in Aeronautical Engineering from the University of Southern California in 1958.
Formerly an aerospace research pilot, Dana flew the F-100 variable stability research aircraft and the Advanced Fighter Technology Integration/F-16 aircraft as well as many others.
As a research pilot, Dana was involved in some of the most significant aeronautical programs carried out at Dryden.
For his service as a flight research pilot, he received NASA Distinguished Service Medal in 1997.

column2: In 2000 he was awarded the Milton O. Thompson Lifetime Achievement Award by the Dryden Flight Research Center.

column1: From 1960 through 1962 he was a pilot astronaut in the U.S. Air Force X-20 Dyna-Soar program.
He was the pilot on the final (199th) flight of the 10-year program.
He completed one NASA M2-F1, nine Northrop HL-10, nineteen Northrop M2-F3 and two Martin Marietta X-24B flights, for a total of 31 lifting body missions.
Dana has been married to Judi Dana since 1962.
Together they have raised four children, Sidney, Matt, Janet (Jan), and Leslie (Cricket); they have seven grandchildren.
He now lives in Phoenix, Arizona.
For his contributions to the lifting body program, Dana received the NASA Exceptional Service Medal.
A member of the Society of Experimental Test Pilots, Dana is the author of several technical papers.
In 1993, he was inducted into the Aerospace Walk of Honor.
On 23 August 2005, NASA officially conferred on Dana his astronaut's wings.
